definitions.definition: to rub your skin with your nails, usually because it is itching

examples.text: John yawned and scratched his chin.
The dog scratched itself behind the ear.
Try not to scratch.
She scratched at the insect bites on her arm.
He absently scratched his head.
He kept scratching at his nose.
He scratched at his beard for a few seconds.

definitions.definition: to cut or damage your skin slightly with something sharp

examples.text: I'd scratched my leg and it was bleeding.
Does the cat scratch?
She scratched herself on a nail.
I scratched my arm on a rose bush.
The cat scratched his leg with her claws.
She had obviously tried to scratch her attacker.

definitions.definition: to damage the surface of something, especially by accident, by making thin shallow marks on it

examples.text: Be careful not to scratch the furniture.
The car's paintwork is badly scratched.

definitions.definition: to make or remove a mark, etc. on something deliberately, by rubbing it with something hard or sharp

examples.text: They scratched lines in the dirt to mark out a pitch.
Some graffiti had been scratched on the back of the door.
We scratched some of the dirt away.
You can scratch my name off the list.

definitions.definition: to make an annoying noise by rubbing something with something sharp

examples.text: His pen scratched away on the paper.
We could hear mice scratching behind the wall.
The dog kept scratching at the door to go out.

definitions.definition: to make enough money to live on, but with difficulty

examples.text: 75% of the population scratch a living from the soil.

definitions.definition: to decide that something cannot happen or somebody/something cannot take part in something, before it starts
definitions.sensetop: scratch somebody/somethingscratch somebody/something from somethingscratch (from something)

examples.text: to scratch a rocket launch
The horse was scratched from the race because of injury.
She had scratched because of a knee injury.

definitions.definition: to think hard in order to find an answer to something

examples.text: Experts have been scratching their heads over the increase in teenage crime.

definitions.definition: to deal with, understand, or find out about only a small part of a subject or problem

examples.text: We left feeling that we had just scratched the surface of this fascinating country.
The investigation barely scratched the surface of the city's drug problem.

definitions.definition: used to say that if somebody helps you, you will help them, even if this is unfair to others

wordOrigin: late Middle English: probably a blend of the synonymous dialect words scrat and cratch, both of uncertain origin; compare with Middle Low German kratsen and Old High German krazzōn.
